qas.question: Aside from Walpole, who else denied that there was no such thing as the prime minister?
Which kings tried to get power back to the monarchy?
During whose government did prime minister first see use on official state documents?
When was the position of prime minister finally formalized?
Who tried to prove the exitence of the Prime Minister?
What monarch gave more power to the prime minister?
Who was loyal to the Commons?
What prime minster was mentally ill?

context: Walpole always denied that he was "prime minister", and throughout the 18th century <a0_0>parliamentarians and <b4_0>legal scholars<b4_0/><a0_0/> continued to deny that any such position was known to the Constitution. <a1_0><b5_0>George II and George III<b5_0/><a1_0/> made strenuous efforts to reclaim the personal power of the monarch, but the increasing complexity and expense of government meant that a minister who could command the loyalty of the Commons was increasingly necessary. The long tenure of the wartime <b6_0>prime minister<b6_0/> <b7_0>William Pitt the Younger<b7_0/> (1783–1801), combined with the mental illness of George III, consolidated the power of the post. The title was first referred to on government documents during the administration of <a2_0>Benjamin Disraeli<a2_0/> but did not appear in the formal British Order of precedence until <a3_0>1905<a3_0/>.
